title: Code of Conduct
text:
This training program runs under the Open Scholarship Initiative Code of Conduct. Please read it carefully before agreeing to join us.
In summary, we expect you to be excellent to each other. If you witness or experience any violation of this Code of Conduct, please reach out to one of the instructors immediately.

title: Resources

External references

Git cheatsheet

title: Setting up your Personal Access Token
text:
Please follow the instructions under the heading ‚ÄòCreating a personal access token (classic)‚Äô to create a Personal Access Token. Generally, you need to have at least the ‚Äúrepo‚Äù permissions toggled ON for the token to provide read/write access to the repositories you typically have access to. NOTE: the Personal Access Token is only available for copying until you close the page. Once you close the page, GitHub will not show you that token again and you‚Äôll have to generate a new token if you forget/lose it.
Follow those instructions, then do the following on all machines you use git on. This command will configure git to look at your ~/.git-credentials file for your GitHub credentials.

git config --global credential.helper 'store'

Then open/create ~/.git-credentials with nano and add the following line, where <GITHUB_USERNAME> is your GitHub username and <PASTE_TOKEN_HERE> is the Token you copied from the GitHub page.

https://<GITHUB_USERNAME>:<PASTE_TOKEN_HERE>@github.com

Save the file and you should be able to do all of your command-line git operations as usual (and without entering your username and password every time).
Please keep in mind that this is effectively a password to your account (although only for whatever you grant it the authority to do), so treat it like you‚Äôd treat any of your other passwords (don‚Äôt paste it into Slack, email, etc.)

title: Git Training - INN
text:
This website contains all the shared resources that support the Git training hosted by the Institute of Neuroscience and Neurotechnology at the Simon Fraser University. Here you will find reference guides, our schedule, the 100 Days of Version Control challenge materials, and more.
This website will be updated as needed, so bookmark it for easy access! We hope this will reduce the amount of information we will need to convey by email, but any major announcements will still be made by direct communication.






Important



Please make sure to review the Preparation page BEFORE the first day of the workshop!


We hope you‚Äôll enjoy it!
If you have any questions, do not hesitate to contact Gracielle.

title: Creating and Editing Files with nano
text:
nano is a text editor that runs directly in the terminal. It allows you to create, view, and edit text files (like scripts, job submission files, or configuration files) without needing a graphical interface.
This makes nano especially useful on Digital Research Alliance clusters (e.g.¬†Fir), where most users usually connect remotely (via SSH) and do not have access to a full desktop environment.

title: Creating and Editing Files with nano
text:
Quick start
Create or edit a file:
nano filename.sh
Save and exit: - Exit: Ctrl + x - If prompted to save, press y (yes) or n (no). Press enter to confirm
For a more detailed tutorial, see here.

title: Creating and Editing Files with nano
text:
Errors
You may encounter Permissions errors when trying to nano a file. You might be editing a file you don‚Äôt own or in a restricted directory. You may need to copy the file to your scratch or change permissions with chmod to be able to edit it.

title: Pre-workshop preparation
text:
Important



Please review carefully the instructions on this page! They will insure you‚Äôre all set for the workshop synchronous sessions. We will not have much time during the workshops to debug individual cases.

title: Pre-workshop preparation
text:
Before November 21st

Create an account on GitHub, if you still don‚Äôt have one
Make sure you have a Compute Canada account and can login to Fir
Fill out this pre-workshop survey by November 21st: https://tally.so/r/A776Ro

title: Pre-workshop preparation
text:
Before November 24th

Set up your personal access token on Fir
Make sure you have git correctly configured on your computer (git documentation here)

title: Pre-workshop preparation
text:
Before November 25th

Read carefully our Code of Conduct and evaluate if you know how to act if you witness or experience a Code of Conduct violation.
Check who is in your group and get their GitHub handles
Identify a real topic to work on together
Create a repository with a name that reflects the theme of your group‚Äôs codebase
